maml:description.maml:para: Copy files to a container.
Attach one or more files to a container. You can send either local file , or uploaded files with file ID.
The ID of the container to which the file(s) will be attached.
The file(s) to attach. Accepts file IDs (as strings), file paths, or FileInfo objects.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note: Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be retried.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such as: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`.
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should be `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`.
Specifies Organization ID used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a message to a Conversation.
Adds a message, file, image, or other content to a Conversation. Typically used to add user messages to a conversation.
The content of the user message to add.
The ID of the conversation to add the item to.
Specifies the role of the message. One of `user`, `system`, `developer`, or `assistant`.
Specifies one or more system messages.
Specifies one or more developer messages.
Specifies the path, URL, or file ID of image files to attach.
Specifies the detail level of the image. One of `auto`, `low`, or `high`.
Specifies the path, URL, or file ID of files to attach.
Additional fields to include in the response.
Specifies the request timeout in seconds. 0 means unlimited.
Number between 0 and 100. Specifies the maximum number of retries for 429/5xx errors.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies the organization ID.
When specified, returns the Conversation object after adding the message.
The ID of the conversation to add the item to.
The content of the user message to add.
Specifies the role of the message. One of `user`, `system`, `developer`, or `assistant`.
Specifies one or more system messages.
Specifies one or more developer messages.
Specifies the path, URL, or file ID of image files to attach.
Specifies the detail level of the image. One of `auto`, `low`, or `high`.
Specifies the path, URL, or file ID of files to attach.
Additional fields to include in the response.
Specifies the request timeout in seconds. 0 means unlimited.
Number between 0 and 100. Specifies the maximum number of retries for 429/5xx errors.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies the organization ID.
When specified, returns the Conversation object after adding the message.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-ConversationItem -ConversationId "conv_abc1234" -Message "Hello, what's the weather today?"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a message to the specified Conversation. No output by default.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-ConversationItem -ConversationId "conv_abc1234" -Message "Please analyze this image" -Images "C:\images\sample.png"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a message with an attached image file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-ConversationItem -ConversationId "conv_abc1234" -Message "Please check the file" -Files "C:\docs\sample.pdf" -PassThru

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a message with an attached file and returns the Conversation object when PassThru is specified.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Upload `sample.csv` file to OpenAI.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ByteArray = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('some text data') PS C:\> Add-OpenAIFile -Content $ByteArray -Name 'filename.txt' -Purpose assistants

dev:remarks.maml:para: Upload a content of bytes to OpenAI

maml:description.maml:para: Add a new Item to the Conversation's context, including messages, function calls, and function call responses.

Add a new Item to the Conversation's context, including messages, function calls, and function call responses. This event can be used both to populate a "history" of the conversation and to add new items mid-stream
The content of the message.
The transcript of the audio, used for `input_audio` and `audio` content types.
The content type (`input_text`, `input_audio`, `item_reference`, `text`, `audio`). The default value is `input_text`.
Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.
The arguments of the function call (for `function_call` items).
The ID of the function call (for `function_call` and `function_call_output` items).
The name of the function being called (for `function_call` items).
The output of the function call (for `function_call_output` items).
The unique ID of the item, this can be generated by the client to help manage server-side context, but is not required because the server will generate one if not provided.
The type of the item (`message`, `function_call`, `function_call_output`). The default is `message`.

The ID of the preceding item after which the new item will be inserted. If not set, the new item will be appended to the end of the conversation. If set, it allows an item to be inserted mid-conversation. If the ID cannot be found, an error will be returned and the item will not be added.
The role of the message sender (`user`, `assistant`, `system`), only applicable for message items.
The status of the item (`completed`, `incomplete`). These have no effect on the conversation.
If specified, instructs the server to create a response after adding this item.
The content of the message.
The transcript of the audio, used for `input_audio` and `audio` content types.
The content type (`input_text`, `input_audio`, `item_reference`, `text`, `audio`). The default value is `input_text`.
Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.
The arguments of the function call (for `function_call` items).
The ID of the function call (for `function_call` and `function_call_output` items).
The name of the function being called (for `function_call` items).
The output of the function call (for `function_call_output` items).
The unique ID of the item, this can be generated by the client to help manage server-side context, but is not required because the server will generate one if not provided.
The type of the item (`message`, `function_call`, `function_call_output`). The default is `message`.

The ID of the preceding item after which the new item will be inserted. If not set, the new item will be appended to the end of the conversation. If set, it allows an item to be inserted mid-conversation. If the ID cannot be found, an error will be returned and the item will not be added.
The role of the message sender (`user`, `assistant`, `system`), only applicable for message items.
The status of the item (`completed`, `incomplete`). These have no effect on the conversation.
If specified, instructs the server to create a response after adding this item.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-RealtimeSessionItem 'Hello. Why is the sun so bright?'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-RealtimeSessionItem 'This is a great question!' -Role assistant

maml:description.maml:para: Add a message to the Thread.
Add a message to the Thread. The message is usually a question to ask the Assistant.
The content of the message.
Specifies an ID of Thread.
An array of images for reference to vision-compatible models. You can specify uploaded file id or URL of image.
Specifies the detail level of the image if specified by the user. "low" uses fewer tokens, you can opt in to high resolution using "high".
The role of the entity that is creating the message. One of `user` or `assistant`
A list of file IDs made available to the code_interpreter tool. There can be a maximum of 20 files associated with the tool.
A list of file IDs to add to the vector store. There can be a maximum of 10000 files in a vector store.
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured format.
Returns a Thread object that the message added. By default, this cmdlet doesn't generate any output.

This switch parameter, when used, ensures that the cmdlet waits for any active run on the thread to complete before attempting to add a new message. This can help prevent errors that occur when trying to add messages to a thread while a run is still active. This parameter is optional. If not provided, the cmdlet will attempt to add a message to the thread immediately, regardless of whether a run is active or not.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.

Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`
Specifies an ID of Thread.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-ThreadMessage -ThreadId "thread_abc1234" -Message "How many people lives in the world?"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add a message to the Thread whose ID is `thread_abc1234``. This cmdlet outputs nothing by default.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Thread = New-Thread | Add-ThreadMessage -Message "Think of ideas for my friend's wedding gift." -PassThru

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new Thread and adds a message. When the `-PassThru` switch is specified, this cmdlet returns a Thread object with the message added.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Store = Get-VectorStoreFile -VectorStoreId 'vs_abc123' PS C:\> $Store = $Store | Add-VectorStoreFile -FileId 'file-abc123' -PassThru

maml:description.maml:para: Resets the common parameter context set by Set-OpenAIContext.
Resets the common parameter context set by Set-OpenAIContext.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Set-OpenAIContext -ApiType 'Azure' -ApiKey 'API_KEY' PS C:\> Clear-OpenAIContext PS C:\> Get-OpenAIContext
ApiKey : ApiType : OpenAI ApiBase : ApiVersion : AuthType : openai Organization : TimeoutSec : 0 MaxRetryCount : 0

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new OpenAI realtime conversation session.
Create a new realtime conversation session. This technically means connecting to the WebSocket endpoint provided by the OpenAI Realtime API.

Once the session is opened, the connection will continue until it is disconnected from the server side or a Disconnect-RealtimeSession is executed. You always need run Disconnect-RealtimeSession when you are finished conversation.
It is recommended that you always specify the model you want to use.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies API type of use. `OpenAI`(default) or `Azure`
If you wish to use Entra-ID based authentication, specifies as `azure_ad`.
It is recommended that you always specify the model you want to use.

Specifies API type of use. `OpenAI`(default) or `Azure`
If you wish to use Entra-ID based authentication, specifies as `azure_ad`.

Decode tokens to original text.

Specifies texts to be encoded.

Close realtime session.
Terminates a connected conversation session. If audio input/output is activated, they are also terminated.
Communicate with ChatGPT interactively on the console.

Communicate with ChatGPT interactively on the console. This command will wait for user input on the terminal. You type your question to ChatGPT and press Enter twice to send the question and see the answer from ChatGPT. You may then ask additional questions.
The name of model to use. The default value is `gpt-3.5-turbo`.
An optional text to set the behavior of the assistant.
What sampling temperature to use, between `0` and `2`. Higher values like `0.8` will make the output more random, while lower values like `0.2` will make it more focused and deterministic.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So `0.1` means only the tokens comprising the top `10%` probability mass are considered.
Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
The maximum number of tokens allowed for the generated answer. Maximum value depends on model. (`4096` for `gpt-3.5-turbo` or `8192` for `gpt-4`)
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`
Suppresses the display of header strings
The name of model to use. The default value is `gpt-3.5-turbo`.
An optional text to set the behavior of the assistant.
What sampling temperature to use, between `0` and `2`. Higher values like `0.8` will make the output more random, while lower values like `0.2` will make it more focused and deterministic.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So `0.1` means only the tokens comprising the top `10%` probability mass are considered.
Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
The maximum number of tokens allowed for the generated answer. Maximum value depends on model. (`4096` for `gpt-3.5-turbo` or `8192` for `gpt-4`)
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

Gets common parameters that are implicitly used when executing functions.

Gets the common parameter context that is set by Set-OpenAIContext. Note: Objects obtained with Get-OpenAIContext are read-only, and changes to their property values are not reflected in the context. To set the context, use Set-OpenAIContext.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Set-OpenAIContext -ApiType 'Azure' -ApiKey 'AZURE_API_KEY' -ApiBase 'https://my-endpoint.openai.azure.com/' PS C:\> Get-OpenAIContext
ApiKey : System.Security.SecureString ApiType : Azure ApiBase : https://my-endpoint.openai.azure.com/ ApiVersion : AuthType : azure Organization : TimeoutSec : 0 MaxRetryCount : 0

maml:description.maml:para: Create an assistant with a model and instructions.
Create an assistant with a model and instructions. An Assistant represents an entity that can be configured to respond to users’ Messages using several parameters.
The name of the assistant. The maximum length is 256 characters.
ID of the model to use. The default value is `gpt-3.5-turbo`.
The description of the assistant. The maximum length is 512 characters.
The system instructions that the assistant uses. The maximum length is 256,000 characters.

o1 and o3-mini models only Constrains effort on reasoning for reasoning models. Currently supported values are `low`, `medium`, and `high`. Reducing reasoning effort can result in faster responses and fewer tokens used on reasoning in a response.
Specifies Whether the code interpreter tool enable or not. The default is `$false`.
Specifies Whether the file_search tool enable or not. The default is `$false`.
A list of functions the model may call. Use this to provide a list of functions the model may generate JSON inputs for.
A list of file IDs made available to the code_interpreter tool. There can be a maximum of 20 files associated with the tool.
The vector store attached to this assistant. There can be a maximum of 1 vector store attached to the assistant.
A list of file IDs to add to the vector store. There can be a maximum of 10000 files in a vector store.
The maximum number of results the file search tool should output. This number should be between 1 and 50 inclusive.
The ranker to use for the file search. If not specified will use the auto ranker.
The score threshold for the file search. All values must be a floating point number between 0 and 1.
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured format.

Specifies the format that the model must output. - `auto` is default. - `json_object` enables JSON mode, which ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON. - `json_schema` enables Structured Outputs which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema.
- `raw_response` returns raw response content from API.
Specifies an object or data structure to represent the JSON Schema that the model should be constrained to follow. Required if `json_schema` is specified for `-Format`. Otherwise, it is ignored.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.

Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Assistant = New-Assistant -Model gpt-4 -Instructions "You are a math teacher." -UseCodeInterpreter $true

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create an assitant with a model and instructions and enable to use code interpreter.

maml:description.maml:para: Generate function spcifications for ChatGPT Function calling from PowerShell commands

Generate function spcifications for ChatGPT Function calling from PowerShell commands The generated function spcification is a hash table that can be converted to a JSON string following JSON Schema. https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/gpt/function-calling
Specify the name of the PowerShell command.
Specifies the descriptive text of the PowerShell command. If not specified, the command help description will be used.
Names of parameters that should not be included in the function definition.
Name of the parameter to be included in the function definition. If this parameter is specified, any unspecified parameters will not be included in the function definition.
If a PowerShell command has multiple parameter sets, the default parameter set is selected by default. If you want to use a non-default parameter set, specify the set name in this parameter.
Specify the name of the PowerShell command.
Specifies the descriptive text of the PowerShell command. If not specified, the command help description will be used.
Names of parameters that should not be included in the function definition.
Name of the parameter to be included in the function definition. If this parameter is specified, any unspecified parameters will not be included in the function definition.
If a PowerShell command has multiple parameter sets, the default parameter set is selected by default. If you want to use a non-default parameter set, specify the set name in this parameter.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Generates a function definition for the `New-Item` command.
Generate a function spcification for the `Test-Connection` command. Only three parameters are included in the function definition: `TargetName`, `Count`, and `Delay`.

maml:description.maml:para: Generates audio from the input text.
Generates audio from the input text. https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/text-to-speech
(Required) The text to generate audio for. The maximum length is 4096 characters.
One of the available TTS models: `tts-1`, `tts-1-hd` or `gpt-4o-mini-tts`. The default value is `tts-1`.
The voice to use when generating the audio. Supported voices are `alloy`, `ash`, `coral`, `echo`, `fable`, `onyx`, `nova`, `sage` and `shimmer`. The default value is `alloy`.
Control the voice of your generated audio with additional instructions. Does not work with `tts-1` or `tts-1-hd`.
The format of audio. Supported formats are `mp3`, `opus`, `aac`, `flac`, `wav`, and `pcm`
(Required) The path of the file to save.
The speed of the generated audio. Select a value from `0.25` to `4.0`. `1.0` is the default.

maml:description.maml:para: Transcribes audio into the input language.
Transcribes audio into the input language. https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/speech-to-text/speech-to-text
(Required) The audio file to transcribe, in one of these formats: `flac`, `mp3`, `mp4`, `mpeg`, `mpga`, `m4a`, `ogg`, `wav`, or `webm`.
The name of model to use. The default value is `whisper-1`.
An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The prompt should match the audio language.
The format of the transcript output, in one of these options: `json`, `text`, `srt`, `verbose_json`, or `vtt`. The default value is `text`.
The sampling temperature, between `0` and `1`. Higher values like `0.8` will make the output more random, while lower values like `0.2` will make it more focused and deterministic.
Additional information to include in the transcription response. `logprobs` only works with `-Format` set to `json` and only with the models `gpt-4o-transcribe` and `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`
The timestamp granularities to populate for this transcription. Any of these options: `word`, or `segment`. The default is `segment`.
The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in `ISO-639-1` format will improve accuracy and latency.
If set to true, the model response data will be streamed.
The format of the stream output, `text` or `object`. The default value is `text`. This parameter is only used when `-Stream` is enabled.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Request-AudioTranslation -File C:\sample\japanese.mp3 -Format text
Hello, My name is tanaka yoshio.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a completion for the chat message.
Creates a completion for the chat message. https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/chat/chat-completions
The messages to generate chat completions.
The role of the messages author. One of `user`, `system`, `developer` or `function`. The default is `user`.
The name of the author of this message. This is an optional field, and may contain a-z, A-Z, 0-9, hyphens, and underscores, with a maximum length of 64 characters.
The name of model to use. The default value is `gpt-3.5-turbo`.
An optional text to set the behavior of the assistant.
Developer-provided instructions that the model should follow, regardless of messages sent by the user. With o1 models and newer, developer messages replace the previous system messages.
Output types that you would like the model to generate for this request. Some models can generate both text and audio. To request that responses, you can specify: `("text", "audio")`
The voice the model uses to respond.
The path of the audio file to passing the model. Supported formats are `wav` and `mp3`.
Specifies the format of the input audio file. If not specified, the format is automatically determined from the file extension.
Specifies where audio response from the model will be saved. If the model does not return a audio response, nothing is saved.
Specifies the format of the output audio file. The default value is `mp3`.
An array of images to passing the model. You can specifies local image file or remote url.

Controls how the model processes the image and generates its textual understanding. You can select from `Low` or `High`. See more details : https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/vision/low-or-high-fidelity-image-understanding

A list of tools the model may call. Use this to provide a list of functions the model may generate JSON inputs for. https://github.com/mkht/PSOpenAI/blob/main/Guides/How_to_call_functions_with_ChatGPT.ipynb

Controls how the model responds to function calls. - `none` means the model does not call a function, and responds to the end-user. - `auto` means the model can pick between an end-user or calling a function. Specifying a particular function via `@{type = "function"; function = @{name = "my_function"}}` forces the model to call that function.
Whether to enable parallel function calling during tool use. The default is true (enabled)

Selects the action to be taken when the GPT model requests a function call. - `None`: The requested function is not executed. This is the default. - `Auto`: Automatically executes the requested function. - `Confirm`: Displays a confirmation to the user before executing the requested function.
High level guidance for the amount of context window space to use for the web search. One of `low`, `medium`, or `high`
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Static predicted output content, such as the content of a text file that is being regenerated.
What sampling temperature to use, between `0` and `2`. Higher values like `0.8` will make the output more random, while lower values like `0.2` will make it more focused and deterministic.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So `0.1` means only the tokens comprising the top `10%` probability mass are considered.
How many chat completion choices to generate for each input message. The default value is `1`.
If set, partial message deltas will be sent, like in ChatGPT.
Whether or not to store the output of this chat completion request for use in model distillation or evals.
Controls the verbosity level of the response. Valid values are `low`, `medium`, or `high`.

Constrains effort on reasoning for reasoning models. Currently supported values are low, medium, and high. Reducing reasoning effort can result in faster responses and fewer tokens used on reasoning in a response.
Developer-defined tags and values used for filtering completions in the dashboard.
Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
This value is now deprecated in favor of MaxCompletionTokens.
An upper bound for the number of tokens that can be generated for a completion, including visible output tokens and reasoning tokens.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion. Accepts a maps of tokens to an associated bias value from `-100` to `100`. You can use `ConvertTo-Token` to convert text to token IDs. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between `-1` and `1` should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like `-100` or `100` should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token. As an example, you can pass like so: `@{23182 = 20; 88847 = -100}` ID 23182 maps to "apple" and ID 88847 maps to "banana". Thus, this example increases the likelihood of the word "apple" being included in the response from the AI and greatly reduces the likelihood of the word "banana" being included.
Whether to return log probabilities of the output tokens or not. If true, returns the log probabilities of each output token returned in the `content` of `message`.

An integer between 0 and 20 specifying the number of most likely tokens to return at each token position, each with an associated log probability. `logprobs` must be set to `true` if this parameter is used.

Specifies the format that the model must output. - `text` is default. - `json_object` enables JSON mode, which ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON. - `json_schema` enables Structured Outputs which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema.
- `raw_response` returns raw response content from API.
Specifies an object or data structure to represent the JSON Schema that the model should be constrained to follow. Required if `json_schema` is specified for `-Format`. Otherwise, it is ignored.
If specified, the system will make a best effort to sample deterministically, such that repeated requests with the same seed and parameters should return the same result.
Specifies the latency tier to use for processing the request. This parameter is relevant for customers subscribed to the scale tier service.
Used by OpenAI to cache responses for similar requests to optimize your cache hit rates.
A stable identifier used to help detect users of your application that may be violating OpenAI's usage policies. The IDs should be a string that uniquely identifies each user.
(deprecated) This field is being replaced by `SafetyIdentifier` and `PromptCacheKey`.
If this is specified, this cmdlet returns an object for Batch input It does not perform an API request to OpenAI. It is useful with `Start-Batch` cmdlet.

A unique id that will be used to match outputs to inputs of batch. Must be unique for each request in a batch. This parameter is valid only when the `-AsBatch` swicth is used. Otherwise, it is simply ignored.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`
An object for keeping the conversation history.
The messages to generate chat completions.
The role of the messages author. One of `user`, `system`, `developer` or `function`. The default is `user`.
The name of the author of this message. This is an optional field, and may contain a-z, A-Z, 0-9, hyphens, and underscores, with a maximum length of 64 characters.
The name of model to use. The default value is `gpt-3.5-turbo`.
An optional text to set the behavior of the assistant.
Developer-provided instructions that the model should follow, regardless of messages sent by the user. With o1 models and newer, developer messages replace the previous system messages.
Output types that you would like the model to generate for this request. Some models can generate both text and audio. To request that responses, you can specify: `("text", "audio")`
The voice the model uses to respond.
The path of the audio file to passing the model. Supported formats are `wav` and `mp3`.
Specifies the format of the input audio file. If not specified, the format is automatically determined from the file extension.
Specifies where audio response from the model will be saved. If the model does not return a audio response, nothing is saved.
Specifies the format of the output audio file. The default value is `mp3`.
An array of images to passing the model. You can specifies local image file or remote url.

Controls how the model processes the image and generates its textual understanding. You can select from `Low` or `High`. See more details : https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/vision/low-or-high-fidelity-image-understanding

A list of tools the model may call. Use this to provide a list of functions the model may generate JSON inputs for. https://github.com/mkht/PSOpenAI/blob/main/Guides/How_to_call_functions_with_ChatGPT.ipynb

Controls how the model responds to function calls. - `none` means the model does not call a function, and responds to the end-user. - `auto` means the model can pick between an end-user or calling a function. Specifying a particular function via `@{type = "function"; function = @{name = "my_function"}}` forces the model to call that function.
Whether to enable parallel function calling during tool use. The default is true (enabled)

Selects the action to be taken when the GPT model requests a function call. - `None`: The requested function is not executed. This is the default. - `Auto`: Automatically executes the requested function. - `Confirm`: Displays a confirmation to the user before executing the requested function.
High level guidance for the amount of context window space to use for the web search. One of `low`, `medium`, or `high`
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Approximate location parameters for the web search.
Static predicted output content, such as the content of a text file that is being regenerated.
What sampling temperature to use, between `0` and `2`. Higher values like `0.8` will make the output more random, while lower values like `0.2` will make it more focused and deterministic.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So `0.1` means only the tokens comprising the top `10%` probability mass are considered.
How many chat completion choices to generate for each input message. The default value is `1`.
If set, partial message deltas will be sent, like in ChatGPT.
Whether or not to store the output of this chat completion request for use in model distillation or evals.
Controls the verbosity level of the response. Valid values are `low`, `medium`, or `high`.

Constrains effort on reasoning for reasoning models. Currently supported values are low, medium, and high. Reducing reasoning effort can result in faster responses and fewer tokens used on reasoning in a response.
Developer-defined tags and values used for filtering completions in the dashboard.
Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
This value is now deprecated in favor of MaxCompletionTokens.
An upper bound for the number of tokens that can be generated for a completion, including visible output tokens and reasoning tokens.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion. Accepts a maps of tokens to an associated bias value from `-100` to `100`. You can use `ConvertTo-Token` to convert text to token IDs. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between `-1` and `1` should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like `-100` or `100` should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token. As an example, you can pass like so: `@{23182 = 20; 88847 = -100}` ID 23182 maps to "apple" and ID 88847 maps to "banana". Thus, this example increases the likelihood of the word "apple" being included in the response from the AI and greatly reduces the likelihood of the word "banana" being included.

An integer between 0 and 20 specifying the number of most likely tokens to return at each token position, each with an associated log probability. `logprobs` must be set to `true` if this parameter is used.

- `raw_response` returns raw response content from API.

Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). command:example.maml:title: --- Example 1: Ask one question to ChatGPT, and get answer. ---
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Request-ChatCompletion -Message "Who are you?" | select Answer
I am an AI language model created by OpenAI, designed to assist with ...

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Multiple questions with context preserved. (chats)
command:example.dev:code:
PS> $FirstQA = Request-ChatCompletion -Message "What is the population of the United States?" PS> $FirstQA.Answer
As of September 2021, the estimated population of the United States is around 331.4 million people.
PS\> $SecondQA = $FirstQA | Request-ChatCompletion -Message "Translate the previous answer into French." PS\> $SecondQA.Answer
En septembre 2021, la population estimée des États-Unis est d'environ 331,4 millions de personnes.

command:example.maml:title: ---------------- Example 3: Stream completions. ----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Request-ChatCompletion 'Please describe ChatGPT in 100 charactors.' -Stream | Write-Host -NoNewline

dev:remarks.maml:para: ! stream (/Docs/images/StreamOutput.gif)

command:example.maml:title: ----------------- Example 4: Function calling -----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $PingFunction = New-ChatCompletionFunction -Command 'Test-Connection' -IncludeParameters ('TargetName','Count') PS C:\> $Message = 'Ping the Google Public DNS address three times and briefly report the results.' PS C:\> $GPTPingAnswer = Request-ChatCompletion -Message $Message -Model gpt-4o -Tools $PingFunction -InvokeTools Auto PS C:\> $GPTPingAnswer | select Answer

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Example 6: Audio input / output ---------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Request-ChatCompletion -Modalities text, audio -InputAudio 'C:\hello.mp3' -AudioOutFile 'C:\response.mp3' -Model gpt-4o-audio-preview

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 1: Get a vector representation of a given input. ---
command:example.dev:code:
Request-Embeddings -Text 'Waiter, the food was delicious...' | select -ExpandProperty data
object : embedding index : 0 embedding : {0.01004226, -0.01884855, 0.01824344, -0.01565562…} Text : Waiter, the food was delicious...

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an edited or extended image given an original image and a prompt.
Creates an edited or extended image given an original image and a prompt. https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/image-generation

(Required) The image(s) to edit. Must be a supported image file or an array of images. For gpt-image-1, each image should be a png, webp, or jpg file less than 25MB. For dall-e-2, you can only provide one image, and it should be a square png file less than 4MB.
(Required) A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 1000 characters for dall-e-2, and 32000 characters for gpt-image-1.

An additional image whose fully transparent areas (e.g. where alpha is zero) indicate where image should be edited. If there are multiple images provided, the mask will be applied on the first image. Must be a valid PNG file, less than 4MB, and have the same dimensions as image.
The model to use for image generation. Only dall-e-2 and gpt-image-1 are supported. Defaults to dall-e-2 unless a parameter specific to gpt-image-1 is used.
The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10.
The quality of the image that will be generated. high, medium and low are only supported for gpt-image-1. dall-e-2 only supports standard quality. Defaults to auto.

The size of the generated images. Must be one of `1024x1024`, `1536x1024` (landscape), `1024x1536` (portrait), or `auto` (default value) for gpt-image-1, and one of `256x256`, `512x512`, or `1024x1024` for dall-e-2.
The format in which the generated images are returned. Must be one of `url`, `base64` or `byte`. gpt-image-1 only supports `base64`.
If specifies this switch, an output of this function to be a raw response value from the API. (Normally JSON formatted string.)
A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.

Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an image given a prompt.
Creates an image given a prompt. https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/image-generation
(Required) A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 32000 characters for gpt-image-1, 1000 characters for dall-e-2 and 4000 characters for dall-e-3.
The model to use for image generation. One of dall-e-2, dall-e-3, or gpt-image-1. Defaults to dall-e-2 unless a parameter specific to gpt-image-1 is used.
The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10. For `dall-e-3`, only `1` is supported.

The size of the generated images. Must be one of `1024x1024`, `1536x1024` (landscape), `1024x1536` (portrait), or `auto` (default value) for gpt-image-1, one of `256x256`, `512x512`, or `1024x1024` for dall-e-2, and one of `1024x1024`, `1792x1024`, or `1024x1792` for dall-e-3.

The quality of the image that will be generated. `auto` (default value) will automatically select the best quality for the given model. high, medium and low are supported for gpt-image-1, hd and standard are supported for dall-e-3, standard is the only option for dall-e-2.

The style of the generated images. Must be one of `vivid` or `natural`. Vivid causes the model to lean towards generating hyper-real and dramatic images. Natural causes the model to produce more natural, less hyper-real looking images. This param is only supported for `dall-e-3`.
Allows to set transparency for the background of the generated image(s). This parameter is only supported for gpt-image-1. Must be one of transparent, opaque or auto (default value).
Control the content-moderation level for images generated by gpt-image-1. Must be either low for less restrictive filtering or auto (default value).
The compression level (0-100%) for the generated images. This parameter is only supported for gpt-image-1 with the webp or jpeg output formats, and defaults to 100.
The format in which the generated images are returned. This parameter is only supported for gpt-image-1. Must be one of png, jpeg, or webp.
The format in which the generated images are returned. Must be one of `url`, `base64` or `byte`. gpt-image-1 only supports `base64`.
If specifies this switch, an output of this function to be a raw response value from the API. (Normally JSON formatted string.)
A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.

Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`
(Required) A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 32000 characters for gpt-image-1, 1000 characters for dall-e-2 and 4000 characters for dall-e-3.
The model to use for image generation. One of dall-e-2, dall-e-3, or gpt-image-1. Defaults to dall-e-2 unless a parameter specific to gpt-image-1 is used.
The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10. For `dall-e-3`, only `1` is supported.

The size of the generated images. Must be one of `1024x1024`, `1536x1024` (landscape), `1024x1536` (portrait), or `auto` (default value) for gpt-image-1, one of `256x256`, `512x512`, or `1024x1024` for dall-e-2, and one of `1024x1024`, `1792x1024`, or `1024x1792` for dall-e-3.

The quality of the image that will be generated. `auto` (default value) will automatically select the best quality for the given model. high, medium and low are supported for gpt-image-1, hd and standard are supported for dall-e-3, standard is the only option for dall-e-2.

The style of the generated images. Must be one of `vivid` or `natural`. Vivid causes the model to lean towards generating hyper-real and dramatic images. Natural causes the model to produce more natural, less hyper-real looking images. This param is only supported for `dall-e-3`.
Allows to set transparency for the background of the generated image(s). This parameter is only supported for gpt-image-1. Must be one of transparent, opaque or auto (default value).
Control the content-moderation level for images generated by gpt-image-1. Must be either low for less restrictive filtering or auto (default value).
The compression level (0-100%) for the generated images. This parameter is only supported for gpt-image-1 with the webp or jpeg output formats, and defaults to 100.
The format in which the generated images are returned. This parameter is only supported for gpt-image-1. Must be one of png, jpeg, or webp.
Specify the file path where the generated images will be saved. This cannot be specified with the `ResponseFormat` parameter.
A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`
(Required) A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 32000 characters for gpt-image-1, 1000 characters for dall-e-2 and 4000 characters for dall-e-3.
The model to use for image generation. One of dall-e-2, dall-e-3, or gpt-image-1. Defaults to dall-e-2 unless a parameter specific to gpt-image-1 is used.
The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10. For `dall-e-3`, only `1` is supported.

The quality of the image that will be generated. `auto` (default value) will automatically select the best quality for the given model. high, medium and low are supported for gpt-image-1, hd and standard are supported for dall-e-3, standard is the only option for dall-e-2.

The style of the generated images. Must be one of `vivid` or `natural`. Vivid causes the model to lean towards generating hyper-real and dramatic images. Natural causes the model to produce more natural, less hyper-real looking images. This param is only supported for `dall-e-3`.

sexual : False hate : False violence : True self-harm : False sexual/minors : False hate/threatening : False violence/graphic : False

maml:description.maml:para: Instruct the server to generate a response.

Instruct the server to generate a response. When automatic turn detection by the server is enabled, this is usually not necessary. If turn detection is disabled, use this command to request a response from the server.
Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.
Instructions for the model.
Maximum number of output tokens for a single assistant response. Provide an integer between 1 and 4096 to limit output tokens, or -1 for no limitations.
The set of modalities the model can respond with.
The format of output audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
Sampling temperature for the model, limited to [0.6, 1.2].
The voice the model uses to respond.
Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.
Instructions for the model.
Maximum number of output tokens for a single assistant response. Provide an integer between 1 and 4096 to limit output tokens, or -1 for no limitations.
The set of modalities the model can respond with.
The format of output audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
Sampling temperature for the model, limited to [0.6, 1.2].
The voice the model uses to respond.
Creates a model response.
Creates a model response. Provide text or image inputs to generate text or JSON outputs.
A text input to the model.
The role of the message input. One of `user`, `system`, or `developer`. The default is `user`.
The name of model to use. The default value is `gpt-4o-mini`.
(Instead of this parameter, the use of the `-Instructions` parameter is recommended.) Instructions that the model should follow.
(Instead of this parameter, the use of the `-Instructions` parameter is recommended.) Instructions that the model should follow.
A system (or developer) message inserted into the model's context.
The conversation that this response belongs to. Input items and output items from this response are automatically added to this conversation after this response completes.
The unique ID of the previous response to the model. Use this to create multi-turn conversations.
The unique identifier of the prompt template to use.
Optional map of values to substitute in for variables in your prompt.
Optional version of the prompt template.
A list of images to passing the model. You can specify local image file or remote url.
Controls how the model processes the image and generates its textual understanding. You can select from `Low` or `High`.
A file input to the model. You can speciy a list of the local file path, the URL of the file or the ID of the file to be uploaded.
How the model should select which tool (or tools) to use when generating a response.
Whether to allow the model to run tool calls in parallel.
A list of functions the model may call.
A list of custom tools the model may call.
If you want to use the File search built-in tool, Should specify this switch as enabled.
The IDs of the vector stores to search.
The maximum number of results to return.
The ranker to use for the file search.
The score threshold for the file search, a number between 0 and 1. Numbers closer to 1 will attempt to return only the most relevant results, but may return fewer results.
If you want to use the Web search built-in tool, Should specify this switch as enabled.
The type of the web search tool.
High level guidance for the amount of context window space to use for the search. One of `low`, `medium`, or `high`. `medium` is the default.
Allowed domains for the search. If not provided, all domains are allowed. Subdomains of the provided domains are allowed as well.
Free text input for the city of the user, e.g. `San Francisco`.
The two-letter ISO country code of the user, e.g. `US`.
Free text input for the region of the user, e.g. `California`.
The IANA timezone of the user, e.g. `America/Los_Angeles`.
If you want to use the Computer-use built-in tool, Should specify this switch as enabled.
The type of computer environment to control. Possible values: `browser`, `mac`, `windows`, `ubuntu`.
The height of the computer display.
The width of the computer display.
If you want to use the Remote MCP built-in tool, Should specify this switch as enabled.
A label for this MCP server, used to identify it in tool calls.
The URL for the MCP server.
Optional description of the MCP server, used to provide more context.
List of allowed tool names or a filter object.
Specify which of the MCP server's tools require approval. When you want to specify a single approval policy for all tools. One of `always` or `never`.
Optional HTTP headers to send to the MCP server. Use for authentication or other purposes.
An OAuth access token that can be used with a remote MCP server.
If you want to use the service connector, Should specify this switch as enabled.
A label for this connector, used to identify it in tool calls.
The ID of the connector. Supported connector id values are: - Dropbox: `connector_dropbox`
- Gmail: `connector_gmail`
- Google Calendar: `connector_googlecalendar`
- Google Drive: `connector_googledrive`
- Microsoft Teams: `connector_microsoftteams`
- Outlook Calendar: `connector_outlookcalendar`
- Outlook Email: `connector_outlookemail`
- SharePoint: `connector_sharepoint`
Specify whether the connector requires approval. One of `always` or `never`.
An OAuth access token that can be used with a service connector.
If you want to use the Code Interpreter built-in tool, Should specify this switch as enabled.
The code interpreter container. Can be a container ID or `auto` to use the default container.
An optional list of uploaded files to make available to your code.
If you want to use the Imagae Generation built-in tool, Should specify this switch as enabled.
The image generation model to use. Default: `gpt-image-1`.
Background type for the generated image. One of `transparent`, `opaque`, or `auto`
Optional mask for inpainting. Contains image_url (string, optional) and file_id (string, optional).
Moderation level for the generated image. Default: auto
Compression level for the output image. Default: 100.
The output format of the generated image. One of `png`, `webp`, or `jpeg`.
Number of partial images to generate in streaming mode, from 0 (default value) to 3.
The quality of the generated image. One of `low`, `medium`, `high`, or `auto`.
The size of the generated image. One of `1024x1024`, `1024x1536`, `1536x1024`, or `auto`. Default: `auto`.
If you want to use the Local Shell built-in tool, Should specify this switch as enabled.
Specify additional output data to include in the model response.
The truncation strategy to use for the model response. `disabled` (default) or `auto`.
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.
Whether to store the generated model response for later retrieval via API. The default is `$true`.
Whether to run the model response in the background. The default is `$false`.
If set, the model response data will be streamed to the client.

Specifying the format that the function output. This parameter is only valid for the stream output. - `text` : Output only text deltas that the model generated. (Default) - `object` : Output all events that the API respond.
Controls the verbosity level of the response. Valid values are `low`, `medium`, or `high`.
Constrains effort on reasoning for reasoning models. Currently supported values are low, medium, and high.
A summary of the reasoning performed by the model. This can be useful for debugging and understanding the model's reasoning process. One of `auto`, `concise` or `detailed`.
Developer-defined tags and values used for filtering completions in the dashboard.
An upper bound for the number of tokens that can be generated for a response.

An object specifying the format that the model must output. - `text` : Default response format. Used to generate text responses. - `json_schema` : Enables Structured Outputs - `json_object` : Enables the older JSON mode (Not recommended)
If specifies this switch, an output of this function to be a raw response value from the API. (Normally JSON formatted string.)
The schema for the response format, described as a JSON Schema object.
The name of the response format.
A description of what the response format is for, used by the model to determine how to respond in the format.
Whether to enable strict schema adherence when generating the output.
Specifies the latency tier to use for processing the request. This parameter is relevant for customers subscribed to the scale tier service.
Used by OpenAI to cache responses for similar requests to optimize your cache hit rates.
A stable identifier used to help detect users of your application that may be violating OpenAI's usage policies. The IDs should be a string that uniquely identifies each user.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.
Whether to store the generated model response for later retrieval via API. The default is `$true`.
Whether to run the model response in the background. The default is `$false`.
If set, the model response data will be streamed to the client.

Specifying the format that the function output. This parameter is only valid for the stream output. - `text` : Output only text deltas that the model generated. (Default) - `object` : Output all events that the API respond.
Controls the verbosity level of the response. Valid values are `low`, `medium`, or `high`.
Constrains effort on reasoning for reasoning models. Currently supported values are low, medium, and high.
A summary of the reasoning performed by the model. This can be useful for debugging and understanding the model's reasoning process. One of `auto`, `concise` or `detailed`.
Developer-defined tags and values used for filtering completions in the dashboard.
An upper bound for the number of tokens that can be generated for a response.

An object specifying the format that the model must output. - `text` : Default response format. Used to generate text responses. - `json_schema` : Enables Structured Outputs - `json_object` : Enables the older JSON mode (Not recommended)
If specifies this switch, an output of this function to be a raw response value from the API. (Normally JSON formatted string.)
The schema for the response format, described as a JSON Schema object.
The name of the response format.
A description of what the response format is for, used by the model to determine how to respond in the format.
Whether to enable strict schema adherence when generating the output.
Specifies the latency tier to use for processing the request. This parameter is relevant for customers subscribed to the scale tier service.
Used by OpenAI to cache responses for similar requests to optimize your cache hit rates.
A stable identifier used to help detect users of your application that may be violating OpenAI's usage policies. The IDs should be a string that uniquely identifies each user.
(deprecated) This field is being replaced by `SafetyIdentifier` and `PromptCacheKey`.
Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION` or `$env:OPENAI_ORGANIZATION`
If this is specified, this cmdlet returns an object for Batch input It does not perform an API request to OpenAI. It is useful with `Start-Batch` cmdlet.
A unique id that will be used to match outputs to inputs of batch. Must be unique for each request in a batch. This parameter is valid only when the `-AsBatch` swicth is used.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Number between `0` and `100`. Specifies the maximum number of retries if the request fails. The default value is `0` (No retry). Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` If not specified, it will use `https://api.openai.com/v1`
Specifies API key for authentication. The type of data should `[string]` or `[securestring]`. If not specified, it will try to use `$global:OPENAI_API_KEY` or `$env:OPENAI_API_KEY`
An object for keeping the conversation history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------- Example 1: Text input --------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Request-Response "How do I make sauerkraut?" -Model 'gpt-4o' | select output_text
Making sauerkraut is a simple process that involves fermenting cabbage. ...

command:example.maml:title: -------------------- Example 4: Web search --------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Request-Response "Tell me a recent top 3 tech news." -UseWebSearch -Model 'gpt-4o'

command:example.maml:title: ----------------- Example 5: Streaming output -----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Request-Response "Implement Zeller's congruence in PowerShell." -Stream | Write-Host -NoNewline

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a completion for the provided prompt and parameters.
Given a prompt, the AI model will return one or more predicted completions. https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/completion/text-completion
(Required) The prompt(s) to generate completions for
The suffix that comes after a completion of inserted text.
The name of model to use. The default value is `gpt-3.5-turbo-instruct`.
What sampling temperature to use, between `0` and `2`. Higher values like `0.8` will make the output more random, while lower values like `0.2` will make it more focused and deterministic.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So `0.1` means only the tokens comprising the top `10%` probability mass are considered.
How many texts to generate for each prompt. The default value is `1`.
Whether to stream back partial progress.
Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
The maximum number of tokens allowed for the generated answer. The max value depends on models.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.
Number between `-2.0` and `2.0`. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion. Accepts a maps of tokens to an associated bias value from `-100` to `100`. You can use `ConvertTo-Token` to convert text to token IDs. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between `-1` and `1` should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like `-100` or `100` should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token. As an example, you can pass like so: `@{23182 = 20; 88847 = -100}` ID 23182 maps to "apple" and ID 88847 maps to "banana". Thus, this example increases the likelihood of the word "apple" being included in the response from the AI and greatly reduces the likelihood of the word "banana" being included.
A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.
Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion. The default value is `$false`.
Generates best_of completions server-side and returns the "best" (the one with the highest log probability per token).
If this is specified, this cmdlet returns an object for Batch input It does not perform an API request to OpenAI. It is useful with `Start-Batch` cmdlet.

A unique id that will be used to match outputs to inputs of batch. Must be unique for each request in a batch. This parameter is valid only when the `-AsBatch` swicth is used. Otherwise, it is simply ignored.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets common parameters that are implicitly used when executing functions.

Parameters set in the context are implicitly used when each function is executed. This eliminates the need to specify the same parameters repeatedly. Any parameters explicitly specified for each function take precedence over those set in the context.
Specifies API key for authentication. API key specified in the context take precedence over environment and global variables.
Specify whether to call OpenAI or Azure OpenAI Service. Supported values are "OpenAI" or "Azure".
Specifies an API endpoint URL such like: `https://your-api-endpoint.test/v1` URL specified in the context take precedence over environment and global variables.
Specify a string representing the API version. This is only valid when using the Azure OpenAI Service.
Specify the authentication type to be used. Valid values are "OpenAI", "Azure", or "Azure_AD".
Specifies Organization ID which used for an API request. Specified value in the context take precedence over environment and global variables.
Specifies how long the request can be pending before it times out. The default value is `0` (infinite).

Note : Retries will only be performed if the request fails with a `429 (Rate limit reached)` or `5xx (Server side errors)` error. Other errors (e.g., authentication failure) will not be performed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-OpenAIContext -ApiType 'Azure' -ApiKey 'AZURE_API_KEY' -ApiBase 'https://my-endpoint.openai.azure.com/' PS C:\> Request-ChatCompletion -Message 'Hello Azure OpenAI'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Because the context is set to use Azure, Request-ChatCompletion is executed to Azure instead of the default OpenAI.

maml:description.maml:para: Set the realtime session's configuration.
Set the realtime session's configuration.
Enables input audio transcription.
Enables the server VAD mode. In this mode, the server will run voice activity detection (VAD) over the incoming audio and respond after the end of speech.
Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.
The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
Type of noise reduction. `none` is disable, `near_field` is for close-talking microphones such as headphones, `far_field` is for far-field microphones such as laptop or conference room microphones.
The model to use for transcription, current options are `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, and `whisper-1`
The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in ISO-639-1 (e.g. en) format will improve accuracy and latency.
An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The prompt should match the audio language.
The default system instructions (i.e. system message) prepended to model calls. This field allows the client to guide the model on desired responses.
Maximum number of output tokens for a single assistant response. Provide an integer between 1 and 4096 to limit output tokens, or -1 for no limitations.
The set of modalities the model can respond with.
The format of output audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
Sampling temperature for the model, limited to [0.6, 1.2].
How the model chooses tools. Options are `auto`, `none`, `required`, or specify a function.
Tools (functions) available to the model.
Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in milliseconds).
Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). With shorter values the model will respond more quickly, but may jump in on short pauses from the user.
Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A higher threshold will require louder audio to activate the model, and thus might perform better in noisy environments.

Type of turn detection, `server_vad` is automatically chunks the audio based on periods of silence, `semantic_vad` is chunks the audio when the model believes based on the words said by the user that they have completed their utterance.

Used only for `semantic_vad` mode. The eagerness of the model to respond. `low` will wait longer for the user to continue speaking, `high` will respond more quickly. `auto` is the default and is equivalent to `medium`.
Whether or not to automatically generate a response when VAD is enabled. true by default.
Whether or not to automatically interrupt any ongoing response with output to the default conversation when a VAD start event occurs. true by default.
The voice the model uses to respond. Cannot be changed once the model has responded with audio at least once.
The speed of the model's spoken response. 1.0 is the default speed. 0.25 is the minimum speed. 1.5 is the maximum speed.

Configuration options for tracing. Set to null to disable tracing. Once tracing is enabled for a session, the configuration cannot be modified. `auto` will create a trace for the session with default settings.
The group id to attach to this trace to enable filtering and grouping in the traces dashboard.
The arbitrary metadata to attach to this trace to enable filtering in the traces dashboard.
The name of the workflow to attach to this trace. This is used to name the trace in the traces dashboard.
Enables input audio transcription.
Enables the server VAD mode. In this mode, the server will run voice activity detection (VAD) over the incoming audio and respond after the end of speech.
Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.
The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
Type of noise reduction. `none` is disable, `near_field` is for close-talking microphones such as headphones, `far_field` is for far-field microphones such as laptop or conference room microphones.
The model to use for transcription, current options are `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, and `whisper-1`
The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in ISO-639-1 (e.g. en) format will improve accuracy and latency.
An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The prompt should match the audio language.
The default system instructions (i.e. system message) prepended to model calls. This field allows the client to guide the model on desired responses.
Maximum number of output tokens for a single assistant response. Provide an integer between 1 and 4096 to limit output tokens, or -1 for no limitations.
The set of modalities the model can respond with.
The format of output audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
Sampling temperature for the model, limited to [0.6, 1.2].
How the model chooses tools. Options are `auto`, `none`, `required`, or specify a function.
Tools (functions) available to the model.
Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in milliseconds).
Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). With shorter values the model will respond more quickly, but may jump in on short pauses from the user.
Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A higher threshold will require louder audio to activate the model, and thus might perform better in noisy environments.

Type of turn detection, `server_vad` is automatically chunks the audio based on periods of silence, `semantic_vad` is chunks the audio when the model believes based on the words said by the user that they have completed their utterance.

Used only for `semantic_vad` mode. The eagerness of the model to respond. `low` will wait longer for the user to continue speaking, `high` will respond more quickly. `auto` is the default and is equivalent to `medium`.
Whether or not to automatically generate a response when VAD is enabled. true by default.
Whether or not to automatically interrupt any ongoing response with output to the default conversation when a VAD start event occurs. true by default.
The voice the model uses to respond. Cannot be changed once the model has responded with audio at least once.
The speed of the model's spoken response. 1.0 is the default speed. 0.25 is the minimum speed. 1.5 is the maximum speed.

Configuration options for tracing. Set to null to disable tracing. Once tracing is enabled for a session, the configuration cannot be modified. `auto` will create a trace for the session with default settings.
The group id to attach to this trace to enable filtering and grouping in the traces dashboard.
The arbitrary metadata to attach to this trace to enable filtering in the traces dashboard.
The name of the workflow to attach to this trace. This is used to name the trace in the traces dashboard.
Set the realtime transcription session's configuration.
Set the realtime transcription session's configuration.
Enables the server VAD mode. In this mode, the server will run voice activity detection (VAD) over the incoming audio and respond after the end of speech.
Optional client-generated ID used to identify this event.
The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.
Type of noise reduction. `none` is disable, `near_field` is for close-talking microphones such as headphones, `far_field` is for far-field microphones such as laptop or conference room microphones.
The model to use for transcription, current options are `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, and `whisper-1`
The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in ISO-639-1 (e.g. en) format will improve accuracy and latency.
